semantic_title: Blood Alcohol Level Coding and Documentation Requirements
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 5. Chapter 5: Mental, Behavioral and Neurodevelopmental disorders > b. Mental and behavioral disorders due to psychoactive substance use > 5) Blood Alcohol Level

content.full_text: A code from category Y90, Evidence of alcohol involvement determined by blood alcohol level, may be assigned when this information is documented and the patient's provider has documented a condition classifiable to category F10, Alcohol related disorders. The blood alcohol level does not need to be documented by the patient's provider in order for it to be coded. See Section I.B.14. for blood alcohol level documentation by clinicians other than patient's provider. (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65-L67)
content.summary: Provides guidance on when and how to assign blood alcohol level codes, including documentation requirements and cross-references for non-provider documentation (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65-L67)
key_concepts: Y90 category usage (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65)
Provider documentation of F10 condition (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)
Blood alcohol level documentation flexibility (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66-L67)
Non-provider documentation allowance (Evidence: pg no: 44, L67)

detailed_rules.rule_text: May assign Y90 when blood alcohol level information is documented (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65-L66)
detailed_rules.explanation: Y90 codes can be used when blood alcohol level information is available in the medical record (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65-L66)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Provider must document F10 condition for Y90 assignment (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)
detailed_rules.explanation: The patient's provider must document an alcohol-related disorder (F10) before Y90 codes can be assigned (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Blood alcohol level does not need provider documentation (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66-L67)
detailed_rules.explanation: The actual blood alcohol level can be documented by clinicians other than the patient's provider (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66-L67)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Verify provider documented F10 condition
Step 2: Confirm blood alcohol level is documented (by any clinician)
Step 3: Assign appropriate Y90 code based on blood alcohol level
Step 4: Reference Section I.B.14 if needed for non-provider documentation

code_ranges.description: Evidence of alcohol involvement determined by blood alcohol level (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65)
code_ranges.requirement: Requires F10 condition documented by provider
usage_rules: Use when blood alcohol level documented (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65-L66)
Requires provider-documented F10 condition (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)

code_ranges.description: Alcohol related disorders (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)
code_ranges.requirement: Must be documented by provider for Y90 use
usage_rules: Provider must document for Y90 assignment (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)

references_to.title: Blood alcohol level documentation by clinicians other than patient's provider
references_to.explanation: Provides guidance on non-provider documentation of blood alcohol levels

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient presents to ED with alcohol intoxication, provider documents acute alcohol intoxication, lab reports BAL of 0.15
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Provider: Acute alcohol intoxication. Lab: Blood alcohol level 0.15 g/dL
step_by_step: Step 1: Verify provider documented F10 condition (acute intoxication)
Step 2: Confirm blood alcohol level documented (0.15 by lab)
Step 3: Assign F10 code for intoxication
Step 4: Assign appropriate Y90 code for BAL 0.15

correct_coding.rationale: Provider documented F10 condition and blood alcohol level is documented, allowing Y90 assignment (Evidence: pg no: 44, L65-L67)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Cannot assign Y90 without provider-documented F10 condition

warnings: Cannot assign Y90 without provider-documented F10 condition (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)
best_practices: Verify provider documented alcohol-related condition before using Y90 (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66)
Blood alcohol level can be documented by any clinician (Evidence: pg no: 44, L66-L67)
common_mistakes: Requiring provider documentation of blood alcohol level
tips: Blood alcohol level = any clinician can document
clinical_context: Important for trauma and intoxication cases
